text: hello my needle drops to thin EPOC tanto
here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for review of the new bug
album angels and devils this is the 4th
full-length LP from london-based
songwriter and electronic music producer
the bug aka Kevin Martin a guy whose
musical experience spans decades and
ranges from dubstep to grime to UK bass
industrial techno experimental hip hop
and it doesn't stop there he is
collaborated with numerous artists over
the years whether that be on full-length
projects guys like Justin Broderick of
napalm death and yes ooh and he's
collaborated with a number of other
artists 'as well just on single songs
through Google having them come on to
his records and under this bug pseudonym
which is just one of his many bands or
side projects or solo efforts that he's
played with over the years he has dished
out quite a few sticky singles
especially off of his last full length
LP which was his most commercially
successful to date and I essentially
went into this new record of his kind of
wondering how he was going to keep that
momentum up would he change his sound
would he focus more on just putting out
more concise singles but I was surprised
to hear that this new record of his I
think has a little less single power and
maybe a little more star power at least
for underground music listeners over
here in America because among others
featured on this LP are Liz Harris aka
grouper there's going to Sufi the
psychedelic hip-hop mystic and Death
Grips which considering Kevin Martin's
work in the experimental hip-hop /
industrial group ice many years ago is
kind of like things come in full circle
there are also numerous features of the
uk-based rapper Flo Dan who you may
remember from a moment or two on the
bugs last full-length LP and with these
musical guests Kevin indulges in a
series of different musical genres
ranging from trap to IDM experimental
hip-hop and industrial music as well as
some experimental dancehall however this
albums variety a
and is guestlist to me are significantly
more impressive than the contents
actually delivered unfortunately at
least for the first half of this LP
Kevin seems to dish out one
underwhelming track after another songs
that cycle through many of the same
parts don't really build that
significantly toward the end of the
track offer very little in terms of
progression a lot of the songs on the
first half of this LP feel more like
motifs or ideas that could start off or
be the first half of more structured
more fleshed out more climactic and more
well-developed songs with multiple parts
the first half of this LP definitely
sounds nice it has a nice tone there are
a lot of nice textures to it there's a
decent vibe going on here but at about
two minutes into each of these songs I
kind of end up wondering okay where are
we going to go next and the answer often
is nowhere else
there's the song Pandy which is kind of
a slow-moving synthesizer interlude
several tracks into the album where we
didn't really need it the track just
builds and builds and builds and builds
very slowly and then at the very end
it's just we're done the song void
featuring Liz Harris is a pretty
interesting track as a great vibe I love
the heavy enveloping warm resonant bass
on this song the ethereal atmospheres
which seemed to have been brought by Liz
herself some of it coming from her voice
some of it coming from like a really
weird spare piece of percussion which
could be anything from her clapping her
hands to smacking a stick on a piece of
wood or something the rattling trap
style high hats on this track are
interesting too it's a very gentle chill
instrumental although I do think that
Liz's vocals may work so much better in
more of an ambient context because they
kind of get lost in the haze of this
instrumental for the most part it's a
beat that to me feel so urban so
concrete and yet the whole thing feels
like it's underwater and then there's
the song save me which might just be the
most aimless track on the entire LP and
features go into Sufi and it's not
really one of his more hard-hitting
tracks here it's
kind of like having a personal
meditation session with going to Sufi
where he's kind of moaning and singing
very quietly to himself for about five
minutes even though it feels like 55
minutes when I'm listening through it I
can take or leave many of the tracks on
the first half of this LP honestly the
only song that I really feel like I have
any strong affections for is maybe me
lost with misread which takes a very
quiet cute and very endearing piece of
dancehall music and gives it some very
industrial grimy sort of tattered
percussion and since it's a song that is
as strange as it is smile inducing and
then once the second half of this album
rolls in it's like a night and day
difference we're getting hard-hitting
grimy bangers it's like a tale of the
two sided album on this record if you
get this album on vinyl you're really
going to be dealing with two different
EPS almost once you flip this thing over
there's the song function featuring
grime rapper mango which is maybe my
favorite track on the entire LP the
hi-hats are so loud they're so sharp on
this thing the bass kicks are huge his
flow his delivery it's just insane high
energy if you're a Danny Brown fan
definitely check this on out and let's
go to the infamous Death Grips song on
this record it's a decent track it's
like reading another grime flavored
instrumental here but MC ride is is over
the song doing his usual vocal mayhem
thing and this verse for him is is
pretty typical but the collaboration
still turned out well and it's
encouraging to see that this first big
collaboration off of an album of Death
Grips --is could mean that maybe Zach or
ride or flatlander could collaborate
with somebody else in the future and
make some decent music to the sonic
assault continues on tracks like [ __ ]
you featuring vocals from warrior queen
the instrumental on this track is insane
and and so are her vocal contributions
to a degree but I do think there are
moments where she kind of gets lost in
the mayhem of the song however my
favorite flowed an vocal contribution
comes on the song dirty to me
instrumentally this track feels sort of
like part two of the song function
except Flo Dan is sort of bringing a
slightly more conscious and socially
aware lyrics in his verses here to tell
you the truth even though this side of
the album is way more hard-hitting and
inherently more engaging than the first
half it is a little one-dimensional this
is an all-right LP I came out liking it
overall but there are some seriously
underwhelming tracks in this tracklist
not only that but the entire album
itself feels a little bit too much like
just a random collection of tracks put
together with no real attention paid to
the flow that they have together outside
of putting the quieter tracks the angels
on the first half of the record and
putting the harder tracks the Devils on
the second half of the record I'm
feeling a decent two strong six on this
LP Tran sweaty if you've given this bug
album a listen what did you think of it
did you love it did you hate it why what
do you think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantan oh subscribe
have a nice day drink your water your
fruits and vegetables get a good night's
sleep believe in yourself
follow your dreams help others whispers
whispers forever
